channel.title: science on Newsround
channel.description: Recent content in science on Newsround

item.title: Scientists discover a plant that appears to have stolen genes from another species - Earth.com
item.description: A plant named Virectaria stellata has genetic traits foreign to its family, challenging the classic rules of plant inheritance.

item.title: NASA rolls out Artemis II craft ahead of crewed lunar orbit - NPR
item.description: Mission Artemis plans to send Americans to the moon for the first time since the Nixon administration.

item.title: Startup company wants to light up the night skies with reflected sunlight - Earth.com
item.description: A company called Reflect Orbital wants to illuminate the Earth after sunset with orbital sky mirrors, raising alarm bells.

item.title: Mysterious Underwater 'Atlantis' Is Like a Lost City in The Ocean - ScienceAlert
item.description: In the shimmering blue waters off Japan’s Yonaguni Island lies a geological wonder.

item.title: Science news this week: ISS medical evacuation, Mars Sample Return canceled, and woolly rhino flesh found in permafrost wolf - Live Science
item.description: Jan. 17, 2026: Our weekly roundup of the latest science in the news, as well as a few fascinating articles to keep you entertained over the weekend.

item.title: A Yellowstone National Park Caldera Is Uplifting For The First Time In Years - IFLScience
item.description: It’s an area bigger than Chicago, and it seems to be inflating. So should we worry?

item.title: Alone in Space, a Chinese Astronaut Heard Something Knock on His Capsule 300 KM Above Earth - Indian Defence Review
item.description: What Yang Liwei heard during China’s first crewed spaceflight still defies physics, sensors, and every known explanation.

item.title: Weird Jet Geometry Around 3I/ATLAS in Hubble Images from January 14, 2026 - Avi Loeb – Medium
item.description: A new set of six images, taken by the Hubble Space Telescope on January 14, 2026, show the brightness map of the glowing halo surrounding…

item.title: How much of your body could you lose — and still survive? - Live Science
item.description: Five vital organs are essential for life, but survival is more medically complex.

item.title: ‘Over the next hour, it’s dispatched, dismantled and butchered, piece by piece.’ This may be the most savage ambush attack we’ve ever heard - BBC Wildlife Magazine
item.description: Discover a delicate alliance between shrub, fungus and tiny forest guardians in the Amazonian understorey

item.title: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-11 to Discuss Space Station Science Mission - NASA (.gov)
item.description: After 167 days in space, the crew members of NASA’s SpaceX Crew-11 mission will hold a news conference at 2:15 p.m. EST, Wednesday, Jan. 21, at the agency’s

item.title: Crew-11 astronauts arrive in Houston after 1st-ever medical evacuation from ISS - Space
item.description: “All crew members remain stable.”

item.title: Indra Group writes off damaged SpainSat NG 2 - SpaceNews
item.description: The operator of a Spanish military communications satellite that suffered a “space particle” strike has written off the spacecraft.

item.title: Satellites Capture the Hidden World Beneath Antarctica’s Ice - Gizmodo
item.description: A new map of the landscape beneath the continent’s ice sheet reveals a previously undiscovered terrain.

item.title: Scientists Reveal Why Humans Lost Their Fur, And It’s Not What You Think - Indian Defence Review
item.description: Scientists uncover the genetic “off switches” that made humans lose their fur.

item.title: Liquid gears could challenge 5,000 years of mechanical engineering - TechSpot
item.description: The study, published January 13 in Physical Review Letters, replaces the metal or plastic cogs of conventional gears with controlled flows of liquid. In their experiments, NYU…

item.title: Scientists Uncover Hidden Earthquake Threat Lurking Beneath Northern California’s Fault Zone - Indian Defence Review
item.description: Tiny, nearly undetectable earthquakes beneath Northern California are offering scientists new insights into the complex tectonic processes at play in the region’s most dangerous fault zones.

item.title: Neutralizing extracellular electron transport disarms antibiotic-resistant bacteria, restores healing in chronic wounds - Phys.org
item.description: An international team of scientists, led by Nanyang Technological University, Singapore (NTU Singapore), has discovered a new method that could speed up the healing of chronic wounds infected by antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

item.title: Mars Has A Massive Impact On Earth’s Climate, New Study Suggests - The Daily Galaxy
item.description: New research reveals that Mars’ gravity quietly stabilizes Earth’s climate.

item.title: Imaging technique captures ultrafast electron and atom dynamics in chemical reactions - Phys.org
item.description: During chemical reactions, atoms in the reacting substances break their bonds and re-arrange, forming different chemical products. This process entails the movement of both electrons (i.e., negatively charged particles) and nuclei (i.e., the positively charge…

item.title: Why Mars is Actively Manufacturing Poison - Universe Today
item.description: Chemistry on other worlds varies widely from that on Earth. Much of Earth’s chemistry is driven by well-understood processes, which typically involve water and heat in some form. Mars lacks both of those features, which makes how some of its chemicals formed …

item.title: 85 Remarkably Preserved Human Footprints Have Emerged on a Moroccan Beach - The Daily Galaxy
item.description: While exploring a quiet beach in northern Morocco, a team of scientists spotted what looked like ancient human footprints in the sand.

item.title: Scientists Discover a Hidden World Thriving with Life in Earth’s Driest Desert - Indian Defence Review
item.description: Scientists have uncovered a thriving ecosystem beneath the Atacama Desert’s surface.

item.title: NASA's Mars Sample Return is dead, leaving China to retrieve signs of life from the Red Planet - Live Science
item.description: NASA’s plans for Mars sample return are effectively cancelled as part of a bill approved by the U.S. Congress, ending efforts to collect Perseverance rover samples that could contain evidence of alien life.

item.title: 3D-printed low-voltage-driven ciliary hydrogel microactuators - Nature
item.description: 3D-printed gel microcilia arrays printed by two-photon polymerization and composed of a soft acrylic acid-co-acrylamide hydrogel with a nanometre-scale network structure are shown to respond to low-voltage electrical stimuli within milliseconds, ena…

item.title: In the stomach of a mummified wolf pup, scientists find DNA from a woolly rhinoceros - NBC News
item.description: Inside the stomach of an ancient wolf puppy found entombed in Siberian permafrost, scientists discovered meat from a woolly rhinoceros — and sequenced its genome.

item.title: SpaceX breaks pad turnaround record at Cape Canaveral with midday Starlink launch - Spaceflight Now
item.description: None

item.title: Detailed map reveals groundwater levels across the U.S. - Phys.org
item.description: How much fresh water is in the United States? It’s a tough question, since most of the water is underground, accessible at varying depths. In previous decades, it’s been answered indirectly from data on rainfall and evaporation. Knowing how much groundwater i…

item.title: Jupiter's hidden depths: Simulation suggests planet holds 1.5 times more oxygen than the sun - Phys.org
item.description: Spectacular clouds swirl across the surface of Jupiter. These clouds contain water, just like Earth’s, but are much denser on the gas giant—so thick that no spacecraft has been able to measure exactly what lies beneath.

item.title: Dominant contribution of Asgard archaea to eukaryogenesis - Nature
item.description: A survey of the reconstructed gene set of the last eukaryotic common ancestor shows a consistent link between Asgard archaea and the origin of numerous, functionally diverse eukaryotic genes, demonstrating the dominant Asgard contribution to eukaryogenes…

item.title: Retraction Note: Antibodies against endogenous retroviruses promote lung cancer immunotherapy - Nature
item.description: Nature - Retraction Note: Antibodies against endogenous retroviruses promote lung cancer immunotherapy

item.title: Little red dots as young supermassive black holes in dense ionized cocoons - Nature
item.description: The highest-quality JWST spectra reveal that little red dots are young supermassive black holes shrouded in dense cocoons of ionized gas, where electron scattering, not Doppler motions, broadens their spectral lines.

item.title: How Mars' ancient lakes grew shields of ice to stay warm as the Red Planet froze - Space
item.description: The findings potentially solve the paradox of how liquid water seems to have persisted on Mars even when the climate grew too cold.

item.title: New Image of the Milky Way Reveals Massive Hidden Structures, What’s Out There? - The Daily Galaxy
item.description: This new map of the galaxy is so detailed it’ll make your head spin.

item.title: New state of matter discovered in a quantum material - Phys.org
item.description: At TU Wien, researchers have discovered a state in a quantum material that had previously been considered impossible. The definition of topological states should be generalized.

item.title: Video captures a baby hummingbird behaving like a poisonous caterpillar to fool predators - Earth.com
item.description: A white-necked jacobin hummingbird chick surprises scientists, scaring away wasps by mimicking a poisonous caterpillar.

item.title: The universe should be packed with tiny galaxies — so where are they? - Space
item.description: There may not be as nearly as many small galaxies in the early universe as astronomers predict there should be, which has big implications for the story of how our universe grew up.

item.title: T. rex grew up slowly: New study reveals 'king of dinosaurs' kept growing until age 40 - Phys.org
item.description: For decades, scientists have been counting annual growth rings—similar to tree rings—inside fossilized leg bones of Tyrannosaurus rex to estimate how old the giant carnivores were when they died and how quickly they grew to adulthood. The best estimates from …

item.title: Most complete Homo habilis skeleton ever found dates to more than 2 million years ago and retains 'Lucy'-like features - Live Science
item.description: Scientists have revealed the most complete skeleton yet of our 2 million-year-old ancestor Homo habilis.

item.title: Scientists Discover Bizarre Form Of Water That’s Both Solid And Liquid - Study Finds
item.description: Scientists discover water that’s solid and liquid. Superionic ice found in lab could explain Uranus and Neptune’s bizarre magnetic fields.

item.title: When does the Nasa Moon mission launch and who are the Artemis II crew? - BBC
item.description: The first crewed Moon mission in 50 years could launch in February, preparing the way for a future landing.
